General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The City of Pharr has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  This Program includes:  safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

The city has address the recommendations of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.   

This executive summary was copied from the June 15, 1999 City of Pharr Wastewater RMP submitted by Enercon Services Inc to EPA.  The city continues to follow the RMP and the RMP was revised on May 20, 2009 by the City of Pharr WWTP staff.  The city continues to strive in making every effort to follow the RMP.

HAZARD REVIEW RESULTS WWTP MAY 20, 1999/2004/2009

1.  Process Safety Information, Question-Are MSDS availa

Section 1-Executive Summary

We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40 C.F.R 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This Program will help prevent the occurence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Pharr believes that preventive maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release). This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Pharr Fire Department is the first responder. 

This emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide, where the substances can be adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area. The City of Pharr has taken steps to train the operators,supervisors, and maintenance crews to be knowledgeable in the emergency response program.  The training includes classroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.

Stationary Source and Regulated Subtances

The Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) utilizes chlorine for disinfection and sulfur dioxide for dechlorination of the treated wastewater.  The maximum inventory and threshold quantities for these chemicals are as followed: Chemical                    Max. Inve

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst case release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined in 40 CFR 68.  A dense gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense-gas model is required since both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are heavier than air.
